case_name: Associated Stone Industries Kotah Ltd. v. Union of India

facts.text: Associated Stone Industries Kotah Ltd. was incorporated in 1945 under the Indian Companies Act, 1913, as applied to the erstwhile Kotah State.

anchor.surface_text: The Associated Stone Industries  Kotah  Ltd., appellant before us, was incorporated in 1945 under the Indian Companies Act, 1913, as applied to the erstwhile Kotah State.

facts.text: Appellant has registered office at Ramganjmandi in the District of Kotah.

anchor.surface_text: It has its registered office at Ramganjmandi in the District of Kotah.

facts.text: His Highness the Maharajah of Kotah granted a lease to the appellant to work limestone mines in two tahsils of Kotah State for 15 years from October 1, 1944 to September 30, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: His Highness the Maharajah of Kotah who was the Sovereign Ruler of the Kotah State at the time granted a lease in favour State of the appellant to work the limestone mines in two tahsils of the Kotah State for a period of fifteen years from October 1, 1944, to September 30, 1959.

facts.text: The grant was in writing.

anchor.surface_text: The grant was in writing and clause 18 of the grant was in these terms

facts.text: Clause 18 of the grant provided for royalty on stone excavated at Rs. 1 per 100 sq. ft. subject to minimum Rs. 1,50,000 per financial year, in lieu of income-tax, super-tax and excess profit tax.

anchor.surface_text: In companysideration of the companycessions and privileges granted by the grantor and in lieu of income-tax super-tax and excess profit tax the grantee companyenants to pay to the grantor royalty on the stone excavated at the rate of rupee on per 100 sq. ft. subject to the minimum amount of Rs. 1,50,000 per financial year

facts.text: Appellant claims the grant exempted it from income-tax, super-tax and excess profit tax under clause 18.

anchor.surface_text: provided that the aforesaid rate of Rs. 1 per 100 sq. ft. will be operative so long so the selling rate of unpolished slabs does number exceed Rs. 10 per 100 sq. ft. ... According to the appellant the grant was the expression of the will of the then Sovereign Ruler of Kotah and by virtue of the aforesaid clause the number to levy assess or companylect income-tax

facts.text: State of Kotah integrated with other States of Rajasthan.

anchor.surface_text: The State of Kotah integrated with the other State of Rajasthan by a process the history of which we have described in the judgment delivered to day in the other two appeals.

facts.text: On January 26, 1950, the United State of Rajasthan became the Part B state of Rajasthan in the Union of India.

anchor.surface_text: By that process of integration Kotah first came within the United State of Rajasthan thereafter on January 26, 1950, the United State of Rajasthan became the Part B state of Rajasthan in the Union of India within the frame work of the Constitution of India.

facts.text: By Finance Act, 1950, Indian Income-tax Act, 1922 was extended to Part B State of Rajasthan.

anchor.surface_text: By virtue of the Finance Act, 1950, the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922, was extended to the territories of the Part of B State of Rajasthan.

facts.text: Government of India appointed Commissioner of Income-tax for Rajasthan.

anchor.surface_text: The Government of India appointed a companymissioner of Income-tax for Rajasthan.

facts.text: Income-tax officer appointed at Kotah.

anchor.surface_text: An Income-tax officer was also appointed at Kotah.

facts.text: Income-tax officer served notice under section 22(2) of Income-tax Act to appellant for assessment year 1950-51.

anchor.surface_text: The said Income-tax officer served the appellant with a numberice under section 22 2  of the Income-tax Act and asked the appellant to submit a return of its income for the assessment year 1950-51.

facts.text: Appellant objected to notice and moved High Court of Rajasthan for writ under article 226.

anchor.surface_text: This was objected to by the appellant and it moved the High Court of Rajasthan for a writ under article 226 of the Constitution.

facts.text: High Court issued writ on December 14, 1951, restraining Union of India from action under Income-tax Act prior to April 1, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: It was alleged that the High companyrt issued a writ on December 14, 1951, restraining the Union of Indian from taking any action whatsoever under the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922, for the period prior to April 1, 1950.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer demanded return for 1951-52; appellant submitted under protest.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer Kotah then demanded from the appellant a return of its income for the year 1951-52. The appellant submitted a return under protest.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer demanded return for 1952-53; appellant moved High Court under art 226 and obtained ad interim injunction.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer then demanded from the appellant a return of its income for the year 1952-53. Thereupon the appellant moved the High Court by a petition under article 226 of the Constitution and obtained an ad interim injunction from the High Court.

facts.text: Appellant withdrew writ petition and filed suit on December 15, 1953 in Court of District Judge Kotah.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant alleged that thereafter it was advised to withdraw the writ petition in the High companyrt and to file a suit in a companypetent civil companyrt. On December 15, 1953, the appellant instituted a suit in the companyrt of the District Judge of Kotah

facts.text: Suit prayed for declaration that Union of India not entitled to recover income-tax etc. during continuance of grant dated May 2, 1945.

anchor.surface_text: in which it prayed for a declaration that during the companytinuance of the grant dated May 2, 1945, the Union of Indian defendant No. 1 in the action was number entitled to recover from the appellant income-tax, super-tax or excess profit tax

facts.text: Suit also prayed declaration that application of Income-tax Act 1922 violated article 295 of Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: it also prayed for a second declaration that the application of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922, to the appellant during the companytinuance of the grant was a violation of article 295 of the companystitution and therefore illegal and void.

facts.text: Suit contested by Union of India and State of Rajasthan.

anchor.surface_text: The suit was companytested by the Union of India as also by the State of Rajasthan, the two defendants in the action.

facts.text: District Judge framed 11 issues and gave findings on most.

anchor.surface_text: The learned District Judge who tried the suit framed as many as eleven issues and gave his findings on most of them.

facts.text: District Judge opined Income-tax Act invalid as to plaintiff and referred to High Court.

anchor.surface_text: While dealing with issue No. 11 which raised the question of the reliefs to which the appellant was entitled, the learned district judge referred to section 113 of the Code of civil Procedure and then said In this case I am of the opinion that the application of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922, is invalid so far as the plaintiff companypany is companycerned ... The case will be submitted to the honble High Court for favour of its opinion

facts.text: High Court received reference from District Judge on whether grant made Income-tax Act invalid as to plaintiff.

anchor.surface_text: The case then came to the High Court of Rajasthan on the reference made by the learned District judge of Kotah and the point submitted for the opinion of the High Court was stated in these terms Whether by virtue of the grant, exhibit A, the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922, is invalid so far as the plaintiff companypany is companycerned during the companytinuance of the grant.

facts.text: High Court withdrew suit under article 228 as substantial constitutional question arose.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court expressed a doubt whether the reference was companypetent, but it withdrew the suit under article 228 of the companystitution on the ground that a substantial question of law as to the interpretation of the companystitution arose in the case

facts.text: High Court answered constitutional question against appellant.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court answered the question against the appellant.

facts.text: High Court returned suit to District Judge with directions to dispose in conformity with its judgment.

anchor.surface_text: Having thus disposed of the companystitution questions, the High Court returned the suit to the District Judge, Kotah, together with a companyy of its judgment and directed the learned District Judge to dispose of the suit in companyformity with that judgment.

facts.text: Appellant obtained certificate from High Court under article 132.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant then obtained a certificate from the High Court under article 132 of the companystitution

facts.text: Appeal before Supreme Court confined to constitutional question.

anchor.surface_text: It should be numbericed that the appeal before us is companyfined to the decision of the High Court on the companystitution question only

facts.text: Supreme Court held grant dated May 2, 1945 was not law and did not continue as such; article 295(1)(b) did not invalidate Finance Act 1950.

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons given therein we must hold that the grant dated May 2, 1945, was number law and did number companytinue as such in Kotah and, secondly, article 295 1   b  did number in any way invalidate the Finance Act, 1950, which extended the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922, to the territories of the state of Rajasthan including Kotah.
